data.name: DescriptionContent2
data.value: Tutorial 1 uses cipher 1 of the DCA ToyCipher component. This cipher works on 16 bit blocks and uses two 16 bit round keys. One encryption round is executed. In this tutorial both unknown round keys are restored.

data.name: DescriptionContent3
data.value: Tutorial 2 uses cipher 2 of the DCA ToyCipher component. This cipher works on 16 bit blocks and uses four 16 bit round keys. Three encryption rounds are executed. In this tutorial all unknown round keys are restored.

data.name: DescriptionContent4
data.value: Tutorial 3 uses cipher 3 of the DCA ToyCipher component. This cipher works on 16 bit blocks and uses six 16 bit round keys. Five encryption rounds are executed. In this tutorial all unknown round keys are restored.

data.name: OverviewContent1
data.value: Welcome to the differential cryptanalysis (DCA) tutorial. This method for the analysis of round-based symmetric block ciphers aims at recovering single bits up to complete round keys. This procedure was published in 1991 by the two Israeli researchers Eli Biham and Adi Shamir.

data.name: OverviewContent2
data.value: This tutorial covers the DCA in three parts. Part 1 conveys the basic idea of the DCA by means of a cipher with only a single encryption round. Part 2 deepens this idea using a cipher with three encryption rounds. Part 3 deepens the knowledge by increasing the complexity of the cipher to five encryption rounds.

data.name: OverviewContent3
data.value: In the configuration of this component the number of the tutorial and the tutorial mode can be selected.

data.name: OverviewContent4
data.value: Have fun trying out and breaking the ciphers!

data.name: OverviewContent5
data.value: (This introduction can be skipped by starting the workspace)

data.value: Differential Cryptanalysis Tutorial

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisHeader
data.value: 2. Differential cryptanalysis of cipher 1

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide10Content1
data.value: The value of

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide10Content2Run1
data.value: is already known. As indicated on the previous page, the values of k

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide10Content2Run3
data.value: guessed. Here is explained how to limit the set of possible correct values: The cryptanalyst tries all values t of k

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide10Content2Run5
data.value: through and if

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide10Content3Run1
data.value: holds true, t is considered a candidate for k

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide10Content3Run3
data.value: . If more than one candidate remains at the end, the attack is repeated with new pairs of plaintext and ciphertext.

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide10Content4
data.value: By clicking the "Next" button again, differential cryptanalysis can be performed on cipher 1 in the "DCA KeyRecovery" component.

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide10Content4Run1
data.value: After successful recovery of k

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide10Content4Run3
data.value: can k

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide10Content4Run5
data.value: be calculated immediately. This can be done by calculating the equation

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide10Content5Run1
data.value: be determined.

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide10Header
data.value: Differential cryptanalysis of cipher 1

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide1Content1
data.value: Here we apply the idea of the DCA to Chiffre 1. The structure of a cipher is usually public, so that all components and their functionality are known. The security of a cipher should never be based on the secrecy of the construction, but on the secrecy of the key. This requirement is also called Kerckhoff's principle.

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide1Content2Run1
data.value: Cipher 1

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide1Content2Run2
data.value: consists of key addition and substitution. The structure can be viewed in the DCA ToyCipher component. We now try to find the two unknown round keys k

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide1Content2Run4
data.value: and k

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide1Content2Run6
data.value: to recover. To do this, we look at the individual steps of encryption. First the key k

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide1Content2Run8
data.value: is added to the input block m:

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide1Content3
data.value: The intermediate result u is then substituted by the S-boxes:

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide1Header
data.value: Differential cryptanalysis of cipher 1

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide2Content1Run1
data.value: Finally, a key addition takes place again (intermediate result v is indicated with k

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide2Content1Run3
data.value: added):

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide2Content2Run1
data.value: The internal variables u and v of the cipher are of great importance in the following, because we use these intermediate results to recover the unknown keys k

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide2Content2Run3
data.value: and k

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide2Header
data.value: Differential cryptanalysis of cipher 1

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide3Content1
data.value: The following figure summarizes the encryption process outlined above on slides 11 to 16.

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide3Header
data.value: Differential cryptanalysis of cipher 1

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide4Content1
data.value: The following figure summarizes the encryption process outlined above on slides 11 to 16.

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide4Header
data.value: Differential cryptanalysis of cipher 1

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide9bContent6Run1
data.value: However, these values cannot be directly compared with the internal values u

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide9bContent6Run3
data.value: and u

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide9bContent6Run5
data.value: as these are unknown.

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide9bContent7Run1
data.value: From equation (1) it follows that if the round key is correctly guessed k

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide9bContent7Run3
data.value: the following applies:

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide9Content1Run1
data.value: The cryptanalyst knows the parameters m and c, but not the internal intermediate values u and v, since k

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide9Content1Run3
data.value: and k

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide9Content1Run5
data.value: are unknown. However, the cryptanalyst can calculate the difference between the two internal u intermediate values from the difference between the two plaintexts. In the following we consider two messages m

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide9Content1Run7
data.value: and m

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide9Content1Run9
data.value: and build their difference:

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide9Content2Run1
data.value: This knowledge can be used to calculate k

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide9Content2Run11
data.value: ). According to equation (1), the difference of the u-values is equal to the difference of m

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide9Content2Run13
data.value: and m

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide9Content2Run15
data.value: . Next, k

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide9Content2Run17
data.value: is "advised" so that from

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide9Content2Run3
data.value: . For this we will consider two pairs of plaintext and ciphertext (m

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide9Content2Run5
data.value: , c

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide9Content2Run7
data.value: ) and (m

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide9Content2Run9
data.value: , c

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide9Content3Run1
data.value: the values of v

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide9Content3Run3
data.value: and v

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide9Content3Run5
data.value: can be calculated.

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide9Content4Run1
data.value: Because the functionality of the S-Box is public and therefore also invertible, the cryptoanalyst can calculate with

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide9Content5Run1
data.value: the values of

data.name: Tutorial1DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide9Header
data.value: Differential cryptanalysis of cipher 1

data.name: Tutorial1IntroductionHeader
data.value: 1. Introduction

data.name: Tutorial1IntroductionSlide1Content1Run1
data.value: In this section we consider the basic idea of differential cryptanalysis.

data.name: Tutorial1IntroductionSlide1Content1Run2
data.value: Most modern round-based block ciphers consist of three basic operations: key addition, substitution, and permutation. Cipher 1 consists of key addition and substitution. Ciphers 2 and 3 also contain a permutation.

data.name: Tutorial1IntroductionSlide1Content2
data.value: The XOR operation (exclusive OR) is usually used for key addition. The XOR operation is a two-digit operator that can be described by the following value table:

data.name: Tutorial1IntroductionSlide1DataColHeader1
data.value: Input bit A

data.name: Tutorial1IntroductionSlide1DataColHeader2
data.value: Input bit B

data.name: Tutorial1IntroductionSlide1DataColHeader3
data.value: result bit

data.name: Tutorial1IntroductionSlide1Header
data.value: Introduction

data.name: Tutorial1IntroductionSlide2Content1
data.value: If the XOR operation is used to encrypt a message m with key k, the ciphertext c is obtained as follows:

data.name: Tutorial1IntroductionSlide2Content2
data.value: The basic idea of differential cryptanalysis is to use the effect of a property of the XOR operation by using the key k twice. If the key addition is performed twice, the following applies:

data.name: Tutorial1IntroductionSlide2Content3Run1
data.value: We get back the original message m.

data.name: Tutorial1IntroductionSlide2Content3Run2
data.value: The XOR operator is often referred to as the difference operator. This name is also used in this tutorial.

data.name: Tutorial1IntroductionSlide2Content4
data.value: Differential cryptanalysis is a so-called "chosen plaintext attack", which means that the cryptanalyst can select plaintext messages and encrypt them to have matching plaintext/ciphertext pairs.

data.name: Tutorial1IntroductionSlide2Header
data.value: Introduction

data.name: Tutorial1IntroductionSlide3Content1Run1
data.value: We take advantage of the idea of using the key twice by using pairs of messages m

data.name: Tutorial1IntroductionSlide3Content1Run3
data.value: and m

data.name: Tutorial1IntroductionSlide3Content1Run5
data.value: . If the difference between the ciphertexts is now formed, the following holds true:

data.name: Tutorial1IntroductionSlide3Content2
data.value: It follows:

data.name: Tutorial1IntroductionSlide3Content3
data.value: We obtain the difference of the plaintexts by calculating the difference of the ciphertexts. This can be used to obtain information about the round keys at DCA.

data.name: Tutorial1IntroductionSlide3Header
data.value: Introduction

data.name: Tutorial1LastSlideContent1
data.value: The DCA is now continued in the DCA KeyRecovery component.

data.name: Tutorial1LastSlideContent2Run1
data.value: In the DCA KeyRecovery component, you can now recover the round keys k

data.name: Tutorial1LastSlideContent2Run3
data.value: and k

data.name: Tutorial1LastSlideContent3Run1
data.value: To do this, you must click on the

data.name: Tutorial1LastSlideContent3Run2
data.value: Start-Button

data.name: Tutorial1LastSlideContent3Run3
data.value: in the DCA KeyRecovery component.

data.name: Tutorial1LastSlideHeader
data.value: Tutorial 1 finished

data.name: Tutorial1PracticalDifferentialCryptanalysisHeader
data.value: 3. Performing differential cryptanalysis

data.name: Tutorial1PracticalDifferentialCryptanalysisSlide1Content1Run1
data.value: In the DCA against cipher 1, the round keys k

data.name: Tutorial1PracticalDifferentialCryptanalysisSlide1Content1Run3
data.value: and k

data.name: Tutorial1PracticalDifferentialCryptanalysisSlide1Content1Run5
data.value: will be attacked. The attack proceeds as described in this tutorial.

data.name: Tutorial1PracticalDifferentialCryptanalysisSlide1Content2
data.value: Click on "Next" (right arrow below) to start the attack. The control is passed on to the DCA KeyRecovery component.

data.name: Tutorial1PracticalDifferentialCryptanalysisSlide1Header
data.value: Performing differential cryptanalysis

data.name: Tutorial1TitleHeaderRun1
data.value: Tutorial

data.name: Tutorial1TitleHeaderRun2
data.value: Differential cryptanalysis of symmetric block ciphers

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisHeader
data.value: 2. Analysis of cipher 2

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisOfSBoxHeader
data.value: 3. Analysis of the S-boxes

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisOfSBoxSlide1Content1
data.value: Due to the key addition, the S-box behaves non-linear. A guess attempt for k3 cannot be checked directly.

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisOfSBoxSlide1Content2
data.value: All S-boxes of cipher 2 behave identically. For this reason it is sufficient to analyze the functionality of a single S-box. Basically it is possible to consider 4 parallel S-boxes as one big S-box, but this would increase the analysis effort. The S-box receives 4 bits as input and also outputs 4 bits as output. The 4 input bits are replaced by 4 other output bits.

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisOfSBoxSlide1Content3
data.value: Remember: Differential cryptanalysis works with differences of messages. In order to examine the S-box, all combinations of input plaintext are considered and their differences are formed. For each pair, the plaintexts are entered individually into the S-box and then the difference of the substituted outputs is calculated. The transitions from input to output difference are noted.

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisOfSBoxSlide1Content4
data.value: The table on the next page visualizes this procedure. There is one line for each possible input difference. There is one column for each possible output difference. The number of occurrences of a particular difference is described by the entries in the table.

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisOfSBoxSlide1Content5
data.value: To calculate the probability of a difference occurring, the number must be divided by 16.

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisOfSBoxSlide1Header
data.value: Analysis of the S-boxes

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisOfSBoxSlide2Content1
data.value: The difference distribution table is shown below:

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisOfSBoxSlide2Header
data.value: Analysis of the S-boxes

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisOfSBoxSlide2InputDifference
data.value: Input difference

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisOfSBoxSlide2OutputDifference
data.value: Output difference

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisOfSBoxSlide3Content1
data.value: The input and output differences and the entries of the difference distribution table are displayed in hexadecimal format.

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisOfSBoxSlide3Content2
data.value: A 4 bit S-box has 16 different inputs and 16 different outputs. If 2 messages are combined to a message pair with disjoint differences, 256 different transitions of differences can be observed.

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisOfSBoxSlide3Content3
data.value: An important observation is that there are differences that occur more frequently than others. There are also differences that do not occur at all. For example, the input difference 8 is mapped to the output difference D 8 times.

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisOfSBoxSlide3Content4
data.value: The distribution of differences is obviously not equally distributed. In practice, S-boxes are not perfect. The cryptanalyst makes use of this fact. Particularly high probabilities help with differential cryptanalysis.

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisOfSBoxSlide3Header
data.value: Analysis of the S-boxes

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisSlide1Content1
data.value: Cipher 2 consists of three encryption rounds with four round keys. Each round consists of key addition, substitution and permutation. In the last round an additional key addition is performed.

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisSlide1Content2
data.value: In the following, the encryption of a plain text block is shown schematically. As in Tutorial 1, the internal states during the encryption process are described with variables u and v. The following table shows the encryption of a plaintext block.

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisSlide1Content3
data.value: In addition, a permutation P() is used in this cipher. This permutation exchanges the bit positions of a block. In addition to the internal states u and v, w is introduced. This state w represents the value after a permutation.

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisSlide1Header
data.value: Analysis of cipher 2

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisSlide2Header
data.value: Analysis of cipher 2

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisSlide3Content1Run1
data.value: You could now try to get the key k

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisSlide3Content1Run11
data.value: . With the plaintexts you are still able to calculate the difference of the u

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisSlide3Content1Run3
data.value: in a similar way to cipher 1. To do so, you would use a pair of plaintext and their corresponding ciphertexts. Then you would guess a possible round key t to calculate the internal variables v

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisSlide3Content1Run5
data.value: . This would allow u

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisSlide3Content1Run7
data.value: to be calculated. Since the round key k

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisSlide3Content1Run9
data.value: is also unknown, you could now calculate the difference of u

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisSlide3Content2Run1
data.value: Due to the Exclusive-Or, the S-box behaves non-linear, so that the difference of the v

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisSlide3Content2Run3
data.value: cannot be determined. Therefore, it is not possible to check a guess attempt of k

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisSlide3Content2Run5
data.value: by using differences.

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisSlide3Content3
data.value: To solve this problem, lets take a closer look at how the S-boxes work.

data.name: Tutorial2AnalysisSlide3Header
data.value: Analysis of cipher 2

data.name: Tutorial2AttackFinishedContent1
data.value: Tutorial 2 on differential cryptanalysis in the DCA PathFinder component is finished.

data.name: Tutorial2AttackFinishedContent2Run1
data.value: A last click on "Start" in the DCA KeyRecovery component attempts to recover the last two round keys k

data.name: Tutorial2AttackFinishedContent2Run3
data.value: and k

data.name: Tutorial2AttackFinishedHeader
data.value: Tutorial 2 finished

data.name: Tutorial2AttackFirstRoundContent1Run1
data.value: In the last step, the last two round keys k

data.name: Tutorial2AttackFirstRoundContent1Run3
data.value: and k

data.name: Tutorial2AttackFirstRoundContent1Run5
data.value: are attacked. This attack is similar to the procedure described in Tutorial 1

data.name: Tutorial2AttackFirstRoundContent2Run1
data.value: By clicking on "Continue" (right arrow below), the first two round keys k

data.name: Tutorial2AttackFirstRoundContent2Run3
data.value: and k

data.name: Tutorial2AttackFirstRoundContent2Run5
data.value: are attacked.

data.name: Tutorial2AttackFirstRoundHeaderRun1
data.value: Calculation of round keys k

data.name: Tutorial2AttackFirstRoundHeaderRun3
data.value: and k

data.name: Tutorial2AttackHeader
data.value: 7. Differential cryptanalysis of cipher 2

data.name: Tutorial2AttackKeyRound2Content1Run1
data.value: At this point, the second round key k

data.name: Tutorial2AttackKeyRound2Content1Run3
data.value: is to be attacked. S-boxes can be selected for this in the second encryption round. By selecting an S-box, the respective 4 bits of the round key are attacked and an attempt is made to restore them.

data.name: Tutorial2AttackKeyRound2Content1Run4
data.value: The attack is almost analogous to the attack on the round key k

data.name: Tutorial2AttackKeyRound2Content1Run6
data.value: . However, when searching for differentials, the cipher does not have to be searched so deeply any more, since an encryption round has already been completely attacked.

data.name: Tutorial2AttackKeyRound3Content1Run1
data.value: At this point, the first round key k

data.name: Tutorial2AttackKeyRound3Content1Run3
data.value: of the cipher will be attacked. S-boxes can be selected for this in the third encryption round. By selecting an S-box the respective 4 bits of the round key are attacked and an attempt is made to restore them.

data.name: Tutorial2AttackKeyRound3Content1Run4
data.value: In differential cryptanalysis, the change of differences at the S-boxes is considered. S-boxes should therefore be selected at this point.

data.name: Tutorial2AttackKeyRound3Content1Run5
data.value: The more key bits that are selected, the more complicated the search for a differential. However, it can make sense to attack several S-boxes at the same time. Depending on the nature of the cipher, better or worse differentials can be found.

data.name: Tutorial2AttackRound2HeaderRun1
data.value: Select S-boxes from round 2 to get key bits from k

data.name: Tutorial2AttackRound3HeaderRun1
data.value: Select S-boxes from round 3 to get key bits from k

data.name: Tutorial2CharacteristicHeader
data.value: 4. Characteristics

data.name: Tutorial2CharacteristicSlide1Content1Run1
data.value: Two entries that differ by a difference

data.name: Tutorial2CharacteristicSlide1Content1Run2
data.value: are substituted using the S-box by a pair of outputs differing by a difference

data.name: Tutorial2CharacteristicSlide1Content1Run3
data.value: . This is noted by

data.name: Tutorial2CharacteristicSlide1Content2
data.value: Characteristics can be combined with each other and thus connected over several rounds. The prerequisite for this is that the output difference of the preceding characteristic has the same value as the input difference of the following characteristic. Assuming that characteristics are independent of each other, the probabilities can be multiplied. In this way, a path of differences through the cipher can be searched.

data.name: Tutorial2CharacteristicSlide1Content2Run1
data.value: We call such a pair

data.name: Tutorial2CharacteristicSlide1Content2Run2
data.value: a differential characteristic under the operation of the S-box. As seen before, a differential characteristic has a fixed probability.

data.name: Tutorial2CharacteristicSlide1Content3
data.value: The goal of the search is to find a path that has the highest possible probability. These paths can be displayed graphically in the DCA PathVisualizer component.

data.name: Tutorial2CharacteristicSlide1Header
data.value: Characteristics

data.name: Tutorial2CharacteristicSlide2Content1
data.value: An encryption round for cipher 2 consists of key addition, substitution and permutation. The cipher works on 16 bit blocks. The previous notation is extended as follows to denote a differential characteristic of an S-box for 16 bit blocks

data.name: Tutorial2CharacteristicSlide2Content2
data.value: After substitution, the bits in cipher 2 are permuted. The permutation of the cipher is known and therefore the differential characteristic of the permutation can be described as follows

data.name: Tutorial2CharacteristicSlide2Content3
data.value: In summary, a differential characteristic of an encryption round as a combination of substitution and permutation is noted as follows

data.name: Tutorial2CharacteristicSlide2Header
data.value: Characteristics

data.name: Tutorial2CharacteristicSlide3Content1
data.value: The differential characteristics of individual rounds are now to be combined into a path of differences through the entire cipher. The search for paths with high probability is a complex and time-consuming problem for ciphers with many encryption rounds and big blocks.

data.name: Tutorial2CharacteristicSlide3Content2
data.value: The DCA PathFinder component has various search options for determining such paths.

data.name: Tutorial2CharacteristicSlide3Content3
data.value: The previously introduced notation is used to denote differential characteristics of a round to differential characteristics for n-encryption rounds (here: 3):

data.name: Tutorial2CharacteristicSlide3Content4
data.value: In the first 4-tuple the input differences of the S-boxes of the first 4 S-boxes are given in the first encryption round. In the second 4-tuple, both the output difference of the first and the input difference of the second encryption round are noted. In the 3rd 4-tuple, the output difference of the second and the input difference of the last encryption round are noted.

data.name: Tutorial2CharacteristicSlide3Content5
data.value: The aim of the search is to find a way with the highest possible probability.

data.name: Tutorial2CharacteristicSlide3Header
data.value: Characteristics

data.name: Tutorial2DifferentialHeader
data.value: 5. Differentials

data.name: Tutorial2DifferentialSlide1Content1
data.value: When searching for characteristics over n rounds, it can happen that different characteristics are found that have the same input difference of the first and output difference of the last encryption round. The characteristics therefore have the form

data.name: Tutorial2DifferentialSlide1Content2
data.value: The input and output values of the difference are decisive for the use of characteristics for differential cryptanalysis. If several characteristics with the same input and output values are found, the probabilities can be added together. A structure consisting of several characteristics is called a differential.

data.name: Tutorial2DifferentialSlide1Content3
data.value: The goal in the analysis of a cipher is therefore to find the differential with the highest probability.

data.name: Tutorial2DifferentialSlide1Header
data.value: Differentials

data.name: Tutorial2IntroductionHeader
data.value: 1. Introduction

data.name: Tutorial2IntroductionSlide1Content1
data.value: In Tutorial 1 the idea of differential cryptanalysis was introduced and demonstrated with a cipher consisting of one encryption round with two round keys.

data.name: Tutorial2IntroductionSlide1Content2
data.value: In this tutorial the idea is deepened and shown at a cipher with three encryption rounds with four round keys.

data.name: Tutorial2IntroductionSlide1Content3
data.value: To attack a cipher with multiple encryption rounds and round keys by differential cryptanalysis, it must be examined more closely. Of interest are the individual components of the encryption rounds and how they behave.

data.name: Tutorial2IntroductionSlide1Content4
data.value: Due to the multiple encryption rounds, this cipher cannot be attacked like cipher 1. For cipher 2, an approach is needed that predicts the changes of differences over several encryption rounds with a certain probability.

data.name: Tutorial2IntroductionSlide1Header
data.value: Introduction

data.name: Tutorial2RecoverKeyInformationHeader
data.value: 6. Recover key information

data.name: Tutorial2RecoverKeyInformationSlide1Content1
data.value: Once a differential has been found with a high probability, key bits can be recovered. For this purpose, the S-boxes are considered where the expected difference is different from 0.

data.name: Tutorial2RecoverKeyInformationSlide1Content2
data.value: A counter is generated for each possible key candidate. The cryptoanalyst generates a number of messages that fulfill the input difference. These are encrypted and partially decrypted with the key candidate. If the difference between the partially decrypted messages meets the expected difference, the counter is increased by 1. This process is repeated with all generated message pairs.

data.name: Tutorial2RecoverKeyInformationSlide1Content3
data.value: The key candidate with the most hits should have the highest counter. This should be very close to the expected value of the differential.

data.name: Tutorial2RecoverKeyInformationSlide1Header
data.value: Recover key information

data.name: Tutorial2TitleHeaderRun1
data.value: Tutorial

data.name: Tutorial2TitleHeaderRun2
data.value: Differential cryptanalysis of symmetric block ciphers

data.name: Tutorial2WaitingSlideContent1
data.value: You can now use the attack configuration generated in the DCA PathFinder component in the DCA KeyRecovery component to restore key bits. To do this, you must click the button "Start".

data.name: Tutorial2WaitingSlideContent2
data.value: Optionally, you can display the determined differential and its characteristics in the DCA PathVisualizer component.

data.name: Tutorial2WaitingSlideContent3Run1
data.value: Summary of the analysis results:

data.name: Tutorial2WaitingSlideContent3Run2
data.value: Input difference:

data.name: Tutorial2WaitingSlideContent3Run3
data.value: Expected difference:

data.name: Tutorial2WaitingSlideContent3Run4
data.value: Probability:

data.name: Tutorial2WaitingSlideHeader
data.value: Differential cryptanalysis is continued in the following components

data.name: Tutorial3AttackFinishedContent1
data.value: Tutorial 3 on differential cryptanalysis in the DCA PathFinder component is finished.

data.name: Tutorial3AttackFinishedContent2Run1
data.value: A last click on "Start" in the DCA KeyRecovery component will attempt to recover the last two round keys k

data.name: Tutorial3AttackFinishedContent2Run3
data.value: and k

data.name: Tutorial3AttackFinishedHeader
data.value: Tutorial 3 finished

data.name: Tutorial3AttackFirstRoundContent1Run1
data.value: In the last step, the last two round keys k

data.name: Tutorial3AttackFirstRoundContent1Run3
data.value: and k

data.name: Tutorial3AttackFirstRoundContent1Run5
data.value: are attacked. This attack is similar to the procedure described in Tutorial 1.

data.name: Tutorial3AttackFirstRoundContent2Run1
data.value: By clicking on "Continue" (right arrow below), the first two round keys k

data.name: Tutorial3AttackFirstRoundContent2Run3
data.value: and k

data.name: Tutorial3AttackFirstRoundContent2Run5
data.value: are attacked.

data.name: Tutorial3AttackFirstRoundHeaderRun1
data.value: Calculation of round keys k

data.name: Tutorial3AttackFirstRoundHeaderRun3
data.value: and k

data.name: Tutorial3AttackHeader
data.value: 5. Differential cryptanalysis of cipher 3

data.name: Tutorial3AttackKeyRound2Content1Run1
data.value: At this point, the second round key k

data.name: Tutorial3AttackKeyRound2Content1Run3
data.value: is to be attacked. S-boxes can be selected for this in the second encryption round. By selecting an S-box, the respective 4 bits of the round key are attacked and an attempt is made to restore them.

data.name: Tutorial3AttackKeyRound2Content1Run4
data.value: The attack is almost analogous to the attack on the round key k

data.name: Tutorial3AttackKeyRound2Content1Run6
data.value: . However, when searching for differentials, the cipher no longer has to be searched so deeply, since an encryption round has already been completely attacked.

data.name: Tutorial3AttackKeyRound3Content1Run1
data.value: At this point, the third round key k

data.name: Tutorial3AttackKeyRound3Content1Run3
data.value: is to be attacked. S-boxes can be selected for this in the third encryption round. By selecting an S-box, the respective 4 bits of the round key are attacked and an attempt is made to restore them.

data.name: Tutorial3AttackKeyRound3Content1Run4
data.value: The attack is almost analogous to the attack on the round key k

data.name: Tutorial3AttackKeyRound3Content1Run6
data.value: . However, when searching for differentials, the cipher no longer has to be searched so deeply, since an encryption round has already been completely attacked.

data.name: Tutorial3AttackKeyRound4Content1Run1
data.value: At this point, the fourth round key k

data.name: Tutorial3AttackKeyRound4Content1Run3
data.value: is to be attacked. S-boxes can be selected for this in the fourth encryption round. By selecting an S-box, the respective 4 bits of the round key are attacked and an attempt is made to restore them.

data.name: Tutorial3AttackKeyRound4Content1Run4
data.value: The attack is almost analogous to the attack on the round key k

data.name: Tutorial3AttackKeyRound4Content1Run6
data.value: . However, when searching for differentials, the cipher no longer has to be searched so deeply, since an encryption round has already been completely attacked.

data.name: Tutorial3AttackKeyRound5Content1Run1
data.value: At this point, the fifth round key k

data.name: Tutorial3AttackKeyRound5Content1Run3
data.value: is to be attacked. S-boxes can be selected for this in the fifth encryption round. By selecting an S-box, the respective 4 bits of the round key are attacked and an attempt is made to restore them.

data.name: Tutorial3AttackKeyRound5Content1Run4
data.value: In differential cryptanalysis, the change of differences at the S-boxes is considered. S-boxes should therefore be selected at this point.

data.name: Tutorial3AttackKeyRound5Content1Run5
data.value: The more key bits that are selected, the more complicated the search for a differential. However, it can make sense to attack several S-boxes at the same time. Depending on the nature of the cipher, better or worse differentials can be found.

data.name: Tutorial3AttackRound2HeaderRun1
data.value: Select S-boxes from round 2 to attack key bits from k

data.name: Tutorial3AttackRound3HeaderRun1
data.value: Select S-boxes from round 3 to attack key bits from k

data.name: Tutorial3AttackRound4HeaderRun1
data.value: Select S-boxes from round 4 to attack key bits from k

data.name: Tutorial3AttackRound5HeaderRun1
data.value: Select S-boxes from round 5 to attack key bits from k

data.name: Tutorial3FilterHeader
data.value: 2. Filtering

data.name: Tutorial3FilterSlide1Content1
data.value: During the execution of the DCA, many plaintext pairs are generated which have a certain difference. It may happen that the messages do not follow the path found in the differential through the cipher.

data.name: Tutorial3FilterSlide1Content2
data.value: If a pair meets the input difference, it does not yet mean that it also meets the last difference.

data.name: Tutorial3FilterSlide1Content3
data.value: When a pair follows the flow of the differential, one speaks of a right pair. On the other hand, a pair that does not follow the differential is called a wrong pair.

data.name: Tutorial3FilterSlide1Header
data.value: Filtering

data.name: Tutorial3FilterSlide2Content1
data.value: Wrong pairs can cause problems when restoring the round key you are looking for. These make it difficult to identify the correct round key by hitting incorrect round keys during recovery.

data.name: Tutorial3FilterSlide2Content2
data.value: It is therefore useful to identify the wrong pairs before restoring the round key and not to consider them further.

data.name: Tutorial3FilterSlide2Header
data.value: Filtering

data.name: Tutorial3IntroductionHeader
data.value: 1. Introduction

data.name: Tutorial3IntroductionSlide1Content1
data.value: In Tutorial 1 the idea of differential cryptanalysis was introduced and demonstrated with a cipher consisting of one encryption round with two round keys. In Tutorial 2 the idea was deepened and shown on a cipher with three encryption rounds.

data.name: Tutorial3IntroductionSlide1Content2
data.value: For this purpose, structures such as characteristics and differentials were introduced.

data.name: Tutorial3IntroductionSlide1Content3
data.value: In this tutorial further techniques are shown, which are used with the DCA.

data.name: Tutorial3IntroductionSlide1Content4
data.value: Cipher 3 consists of five encryption rounds and six round keys. The already demonstrated code will be deepened with this cipher.

data.name: Tutorial3IntroductionSlide1Header
data.value: Introduction

data.name: Tutorial3IntroductionSlide3Content1
data.value: Two techniques for filtering are presented below.

data.name: Tutorial3IntroductionSlide3Content2
data.value: The first technique considered is the difference between the ciphertexts of a pair. When attacking with DCA not all S-boxes of an encryption round are attacked at the same time, but often only a subset.

data.name: Tutorial3IntroductionSlide3Content3
data.value: The S-boxes where the difference 0 goes in, also the difference 0 comes out. Consequently, by considering the ciphertext difference some pairs are already excluded if the difference at the corresponding places is different from 0.

data.name: Tutorial3IntroductionSlide3Header
data.value: Filtering

data.name: Tutorial3IntroductionSlide4Content1
data.value: Secondly, the last (expected) difference of the differential can be considered.

data.name: Tutorial3IntroductionSlide4Content2
data.value: This value is known and the output value of the S-box can be determined by looking at the difference distribution table of the S-box. In general, several different values are possible here. These values can also be used when considering the difference of the ciphertext.

data.name: Tutorial3IntroductionSlide4Content3
data.value: If the ciphertext difference at the position of the S-box does not correspond to one of the different output values of the S-box, this pair can also be identified as the wrong pair.

data.name: Tutorial3IntroductionSlide4Header
data.value: Filtering

data.name: Tutorial3NeededPairsHeader
data.value: 3. Number of necessary pairs

data.name: Tutorial3NeededPairsSlide1Content1
data.value: The necessary number of pairs depends essentially on certain factors. These are the probability of the differential found, the number of key bits attacked by the differential, and the filtering technique.

data.name: Tutorial3NeededPairsSlide1Content2
data.value: It describes the ratio of the number of pairs following the differential to the average frequency of the wrong subkeys.

data.name: Tutorial3NeededPairsSlide1Content2Run1
data.value: A common formula for determining the necessary pairs N

data.name: Tutorial3NeededPairsSlide1Content2Run2
data.value: D

data.name: Tutorial3NeededPairsSlide1Content2Run3
data.value: is

data.name: Tutorial3NeededPairsSlide1Content3
data.value: where c is a small constant and DP is the probability of the difference.

data.name: Tutorial3NeededPairsSlide1Content4
data.value: An example value for c is 10.

data.name: Tutorial3NeededPairsSlide1Header
data.value: Number of necessary pairs

data.name: Tutorial3SignalToNoiseHeader
data.value: 4. Signal-to-noise ratio

data.name: Tutorial3SignalToNoiseSlide1Content1
data.value: A tool for assessing the chances of success is the so-called signal-to-noise ratio.

data.name: Tutorial3SignalToNoiseSlide1Content3
data.value: To determine the signal-to-noise ratio, average values to be determined experimentally are sometimes necessary, such as the percentage of pairs that are removed by the filterng or the average number of subkey candidates that a pair proposes.

data.name: Tutorial3SignalToNoiseSlide1Content4
data.value: The online help of the DCA PathFinder component contains further literature information on the DCA procedure.

data.name: Tutorial3SignalToNoiseSlide1Header
data.value: Signal-to-noise ratio

data.value: Tutorial

data.value: Differential cryptanalysis of symmetric block ciphers

data.name: UseOfflinePaths
data.value: Precalculated data

data.name: UseOfflinePathsToolTip
data.value: If this setting is selected, no search for characteristics, but are used for the respective box number uses precalculated data that is stored in the component. are. This allows long calculation times to be minimized.
